awd_titl_txt: CREST Center for Next Generation Multifunctional Composites (NextGen Composites Phase II)
awd_abstract_narration:
Center for Next Generation Multifunctional Composites

The Centers of Research Excellence in Science and Technology (CREST) program supports the enhancement of research capabilities of minority-serving institutions through the establishment of centers that effectively integrate education and research. CREST promotes the development of new knowledge, enhancements of the research productivity of individual faculty, and an expanded presence of students historically underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics disciplines.

With CREST program support, Southern University and A&M College in Baton Rouge will continue development of its Next Generation Multifunctional Composites Center in collaboration with Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge Community College and industrial partners. This work will have a significant impact on the design and synthesis of polymer based materials for biological and technical applications The increased use of composites in applications, such as automotive, naval, aerospace, energy generation, and transportation vehicles, where light weight, damage tolerance, and multifunctionality are major factors, highlights the need for materials research.

The Center will promote advancements in polymer matrix composite materials synthesis and characterization, modeling and simulation, and manufacturing for structural and environmental applications. Center research is divided into three subprojects. Subproject I will contribute to the understanding of 1) Design, synthesis, and characterization of high stiffness shape memory thermoset polymer with dynamic covalent bond exchange network for intrinsic crack healing; 2) Modeling and manufacturing of polymeric artificial muscles made of chemically cross-linked two-way shape memory polymers; and 3) Healing efficiency evaluation of composite panels. In Subproject 2, knowledge of a new and highly energy efficient method for large scale synthesis of carbon nanotubes will be created. The new synthesis method can be used for mass production of carbon nanotubes at much lower production cost than production by prevailing methods such as chemical vapor deposition. In Subproject 3, the focus is on creating knowledge via computational material design for the study of additive manufacturing of smart conductive polymer nanocomposites with multi-scale porosity.

The development of cutting edge interdisciplinary research based on next generation composites and educational activities through this Center will provide students traditionally underrepresented in the STEM disciplines with meaningful research experiences at a readily accessible advanced research facility and a pathway to Ph.D. programs. The Center will provide education and research integration and exposure to students from K-16 to the doctoral level, and to the general public, including persons with disabilities. Overall, each year the Center will directly support 3 postdoctoral fellows, 3 Ph.D. students, 9 Master's students, and 18 undergraduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Southern University and A&M College in collaboration with Louisiana State University and supported by the National Science Foundation Center of Research Excellence in Science and Technology established the Next Generation Multifunctional Composites Center Phase II. This research and educational thrust focused on scientific understanding and technology development in next generation multifunctional composite materials, and associated educational activities that provided students in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) with excellent educational and training opportunities.  Three subprojects anchored the center: I. Artificial Muscle-Reinforced Thermoset Polymer Composite with Dynamic Covalent Bond Network for Structural Scale Damage; II. Synthesis, Characterization, and Modeling of Functionalized Carbon Nanomaterials for Multifunctional Composites, and III. Smart Multi-Scale Porous Polymer Nanocomposite for Structural Application through Additive Manufacturing.

Intellectual Merit:  1) Subproject I, created knowledge and provided fundamental understanding on 1) Design, synthesis, and characterization of high stiffness shape memory thermoset polymer with dynamic covalent bond exchange network for intrinsic crack healing; 2) Modeling and manufacturing of polymeric artificial muscles made of chemically cross-linked two-way shape memory polymers; and 3) Healing efficiency evaluation of composite panels. In Subproject 2, knowledge of a new and highly energy efficient method for large scale synthesis of carbon nanotubes (CNT) has been created. The new synthesis method can be used for mass production of CNTs at much lower production cost than production by prevailing methods such as chemical vapor deposition. Knowledge on multifunctional CNT polymer composites for electromagnetic wave absorption in aerospace structures was also obtained. In Subproject 3, new knowledge was created on using machine learning to optimize mechanical metamaterials and to print these porous structures for engineering applications.

Broader Impacts: Refereed Publications: The Center has published over 102  peer-reviewed journal papers and proceedings papers in some leading solid mechanics and polymer composite journals. Research investigators have given invited talks and keynote presentation at national and international conferences.

Research Products: Six US Patents were derived from the center’s research activities; 1. "Catalyst Production" Patent No. 16/253,618 ; 2. Shape Memory Polymers (SMP) . Patent No. 62/616,470 ; 3. “Multifunctional Carbon Nanotubes-Glass Fiber-Epoxy Composites with High Density Interfaces for Microwave Absorption and Structural Materials”. Patent No. 17/965,722, 4.  High performance and recyclable thermoset ink for 3D or 4D printing. US11332565B2, 5.Self-healing composite of thermoset polymer and programmed super contraction fibers. US11767263B2. 6. “3D Printable Carbonated Polymer,” US20240409708.

Human Resource Development: In the last six years 23 CREST Centers MS graduate students have been accepted into PhD programs nationwide and two recent graduates have accepted post-doctoral positions. CREST directly supported over 150 students, 8 postdocs and has impacted over 300 students through courses and organized STEM conferences. Twelve faculty researchers were also supported. The students include 98 undergraduates and 52 are graduate students; 93 are African American; 43 are women. Of the forty three women, nine are master’s students and 3 are doctoral students. The disciplines impacted are BS and Master of Engibneering in Civil, Electrical and Mechanical Engineering Material Science, Chemistry and Biology, PhD Environmental Toxicology program (1), PhD Science and Mathematics Education (2). CREST has also been very instrumental in streamlining students and postdocs into the workforce.  Center Graduates and Postdocs have secured engineering and technical positions in more than 15 highly reputable companies and in the academia. Postdocs: Four female and four male post-doctoral associates were trained. Highlights of Leveraging NSF CREST Resources with Other NSF Funded Projects: NextGenC3 collaborated with NSF funded projects at SU as follows: 1) NSF RII Track I  - Consortium for Innovations in Manufacturing and Materials (CIMM);  2) RII Track I Louisiana Materials Design Alliance (LAMDA); 3) Louis Stokes Louisiana Alliance for Minority Participation organizing joint professional development seminars for undergraduate students; 4) NASA University Leadership project in collaboration with the University of Delaware Center for Composite Materials, 5) CREST PI also collaborated with NASA Marshal Space Flight Center on two NASA Cooperative agreement awards that resulted in three refereed journal publications. 

Major research equipment such as a Dynamic Mechanical Analysis, High-Performance Servo-Hydraulic tensile and Fatigue Test System, FTIR spectroscope, and 3-D Printers, were acquired. CREST students participated in the academic year Research Experience for Undergraduates and presented their work at conferences such as Emerging Researchers National Conference, ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and American Society of Composites. Active outreach to K-12 included supporting, and mentoring high school students, which impact over 600 students per year.

Dissemination of Outputs: The Center’s activities were disseminated through center’s active website, social media outlets, and refereed publications. Participants attended more than 20 national, and 10 international conferences with acclaimed presentations of research work.  An annual symposium with proceedings of presentations was  organized by the Center at SU.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/20/2025
Modified by: Patrick F Mensah
